comment.author: 65386747@N00
comment._content:
Imagine... each of the gentlemen there sure had a different plan deep down.
They can be a good plan for their various community or party or individuals or personal.
Some of them might be not that good. A few might be bad and very bad. Et cetera.

Now, where are they and those plans? Did they change anything for the goodness of themselves living on this earth? Answer for your own conscience. For God's sake you are having a chance to be honest with yourself once in your life. Give it a try.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: There were 112 politicians in the Federal Parliament when it moved to Canberra in 1927. (See Appendix 1 for a full list of Senators and Members in 1927.) There were 36 Senators and 76 Members. The Nationalist/Country Party Coalition was in Government and clearly had the numbers (see Appendices 13 and 14 showing party affiliation) in both Houses. The Parliament consisted only of men and it was another 16 years before the first woman was elected. (Dame Enid Lyons was elected to the seat of Darwin [Tasmania] in 1943). Their salary was 1000 per annum and there was no general change in that salary until 1947, when it was increased by 500. (In fact during the Great Depression politicians salaries were reduced. In 1932 they received 750 per annum and it was not until 1938 that they were restored to their 1927 level.) The politicians who took their seats in 1927 were a diverse lot (except that they were all male). There were 34 New South Welshmen (28 MHRs and 6 Senators); 26 Victorians (20 and 6); 16 Queenslanders (10 and 6); 11 Western Australians (5 and 6); 12 South Australians (7 and 6); 11 Tasmanians (5 and 6) and 1 from the Northern Territory. There were 29 farmers, graziers and pastoralists; 15 lawyers; 6 miners; 6 journalists and 4 school teachers. The average age of the MHRs was 52 compared with 56 in the Senate. The youngest Member was Roland Green, 32 (Richmond, NSW), who had lost a leg in the Great War. The oldest Member was John West (East Sydney NSW), 76, a plumber by occupation. Eighty three of the 112 Members were born in Australia and the remainder were born in either New Zealand or the United Kingdom. Thirty per cent of Members had a secondary education and 22 per cent had a tertiary qualification.(32) Reference: Parliament of Australia website. www.aph.gov.au/ (accessed May 20, 2011)
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment._content: The information is just as interesting as the photograph!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Can anyone identify the politicians? Are they politicians or are they members of the press corps? I initially thought that the Indian gentleman sipping tea might have been Dewan Bahadur T. Rangachariar (ca. 1865-1945), former Deputy-President of the Indian Central Assembly, who represented the Government of India at the opening of Parliament House, Canberra, in May 1927. But the accompanying pic indicates otherwise - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3852374 . Perhaps this chap was a member of Rangachariar's entourage (which I gather from various newspaper items included two of his sons) , or even a journalist. If anyone is interested, there's a good pic of Rangachariar at - mildenhall.moadoph.gov.au/photo/1046

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The guy in the middle with the hat looks not dissimilar to Billy Hughes

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R._K._Shanmukham_Chetty As you can see from the pics accompanying the wikipedia article, the Indian chap is R.K. Shanmukham Chetty...really should have worked this out before now...my excuse is...if you've maybe read a few books about the Indian independence movement...well, chances are you'll have learned a little about the big part players...figures such as C.R. Das, Motilal and Jarwaharwal Nehru, Jinnah, Gandhi and maybe one or two others. But you probably won't know much about the thousands of lesser players...particularly the so-called 'loyal' nationalists, such as Shanmukham Chetty, who in the 1920s-1940s were prepared to participate in constitutional politics and accept the limited level of self-government then on offer...they tend not to rate in the grand narratives... R.K. Shanmukham Chetty was one of a number of Empire Parliamentary Association delegates who visited Australia in 1926...there are quite a few newspaper items and pics which can be tracked down that provide further info on their visit - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article38026470 (at Parliament House, Perth); nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16318817 (interview with Shanmukham Chetty) ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article51369821 (delegates on tour in Victoria) ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-page8799140 (delegates at large in Adelaide) ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16333355 (SMH report on the Canberra activities) ; The digitised newspapers also indicate that Shanmukham Chetty visited Australia (and Canberra) in 1941, but I'd say this pic involves his 1926 visit. Whilst in Canberra, some of the delegates planted trees... mildenhall.moadoph.gov.au/photo/2275 ; www.flickr.com/photos/archivesact/5262589197/in/set-72157... Given we now know the location and now the approximate date, it should be easier to sort out who the other chaps in this pic are...the newspaper reports indicate the Empire Parliamentary Association delegates arrived in Canberra on the train from Sydney on the evening of 10 October 1926...and departed on 14 October for Harden...One point we need to keep in mind is that the Australian parliament was located in Melbourne until 1927...I'd say that Canberra wouldn't have exactly been brim full of politicians and department heads and other hangers on at the time this pic was taken. Per the newspaper reports, most of the Australian Cabinet and several members of the Opposition travelled to Canberra specifically to meet with the EPA delegates...the newspaper reports indicate they released some hot air together in the yet to be opened Parliament House...but I haven't been able to identify any of the Cabinet ministers or Opposition members in this pic... trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/1207563 This Canberra Times item gives a more detailed itinerary...it doesn't mention a visit to Lanyon, but I'd say there's little doubt that's where this pic was taken... nla.gov.au/nla.news-page20360 more from the horse's mouth...
